moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc: 9. ... e5! Best of all economic modification of the typical Scheveningen with blowing up the center.
To more simple but quite reasonable game for black leads 13. ... Ne4.
moves.14. Nxd5 Ndxe5 15. c4 Bg5 16. Nc5: Hard to believe but this outwardly active move appears as an origin of a transition of the game initiative to black.  Better 16. Qc1! As was proved in a theoretical part.
moves.16... Bxf4 17. Rxf4 b6: 17. ... b6! Suddenly emerges that after 18. Nxe6 fe 19. Rxf8+ Qxf8  white have to fight for an equality, since they have nothing to attack on e6 and a bunch of Knights c6-e5 dominate in the center.
moves.18. Ne4 b5 19. b3: After 19. cb Bxd5 20. bc Ng6 white have losses.
moves.19... bxc4 20. Bxc4 Kh8: 20. ... Kh8! White's situation in the center is unstable and they should have tried to strengthen it. For example by 21. h3 f5 22. Nec3. Instead of this white were tempted with illusive perspective of attack on Black's King.
moves.21... Bxd5 22. Bxd5: Inappropriate 22.Rd1 because of 22. ... g6! 23. Qf6 (23.Qe2 Bxc4) 23. ... Bxe4. 24. Rxd8 Rfxd8.  25. h3 f5. 26. Rh4 Rd7.
moves.22... Qxd5 23. Rh4 h6 24. Rd1 Qa5: 24. ... Qa5!. Weakness of a first horizontal keeps out a rook from participation in attack - 25.Rd6. Inappropriate 25. Qg5 f6! 26.Rxh6+ gh. 27.Qxh6+ Kg8. 28. Nxf6 Rxf6. 29. Qxf6 Qc7.  Out of despair white tries to break through to h7, but it's clear, things look bad.
moves.25. b4 Qxb4 26. Nf6 Qe7 27. Rf1 Rfd8: White resigned. To 28.Qg5 black have 28. ... Qxf6!
